boat.full_description:
'Nora', a Morecambe Bay Prawner, was built by the Crossfields in 1912.

The first owner, Robert (Rodding) Wilson, insured the 31' shrimper for £65 in 1926. He also insured his punt for £10 paying a premium of 19s. 7d. John 'Shiney' Mount insured her for £60 in 1935, keeping her with the Mutual until 1943, when she was insured for £265 at a premium of £13 0s. 5d.

Harry Allan remembered 'Shiney' Mount heading out to go prawning off Blackpool at 1 to 2 am on a foggy night in 1937. The Allan’s were in 'Alice Allan' LR 170 and 'Shiney' in 'Nora' got in amongst the Fleetwood midwater fleet. 'Shiney' decided against motoring through the press of bigger boats, and put Nora’s helm up to go back. Unfortunately 'Nora' rammed 'Alice Allan' broadside, cutting her down to the water and smashing the pump.

The production of courlene netting caused the Morecambe Trawlers Co-operative Society Ltd. to close its net loft in 1953. The goodwill was sold to one of the lofts' last apprentices, Mr E Nicholson, who holds the records of the lofts. The final year trading included a net made for 'Nora' LR 59 in 1952, a 17' shrimp trawl costing £17 10s 0d.

'Nora' was refitted in 1952 for Frank Brooks, a Morecambe Chemist.
boat.construction_details: Carvel larch planking on sawn oak frames
boat.short_description: 'Nora', LR 59, was built for Robert (Rodding) Wilson by William Crossfield in 1912.
